segments.text: find 90% of it noise.
I don't mean literal noise, but I mean stuff you can't use.
I lecture the same way.
I never stick to the point.
Well, is it rolling?
It wouldn't be Pilgrimage.
Not that I don't like the story.
I do.
But I'm ashamed of having written it.
And the reason is that Pilgrimage is about my wife's hometown.
Jefferson.
And the image that comes out there and the satire, irony, whatever you want to call it, represents a view that I don't hold any longer.
And I caused some unhappiness to people in Jefferson who read that story.
I guess this is an age-old problem for a writer.
But there were people that I liked.
and people that I would not willingly have insulted for the world.
And those people have always been very kind to me, so I do have this ambivalent feeling about it.
I like this story, but in a way, I wish I'd never written it.
And I didn't mean it quite as harshly as I think it came out in print.
You know, I was having fun, and there are some funny things about Jefferson.
But you get older, and you have children of your own,

you get to the point where you catch yourself thinking, well, you know, if I had to pick a place where I'd like my kids to grow up, I could do a lot worse than Jefferson, and I'd feel rather more comfortable with them growing up there than here in Austin.
So there's that.
That doesn't answer your question.
You like different stories for different reasons, and I suppose to some extent it depends on what day you catch a writer and which one you like.
But I guess ones that more or less stick in my mind that I'm fond of, for one reason or another, would probably be Artifact, which is a long and short story, but it is technically a short story.
And probably didn't he ramble.
It's the jazz story, as far as short stories go.
I don't know.
You ask me tomorrow, I'm going to choose two of them.
That's always a problem.
I think a stick for Harry Eddington is a good story, too.
But I don't know.
It's very difficult to judge your own stuff.
I've enjoyed most all of your things that have been said in Africa, or revolving in that area in particular.
Thanks.
And far from this earth, particularly like myself.
Thank you.
This is one of the top.
I'm happy to hear it, not so much because it's set in Africa, but simply because it's one of my later things.
You know, you like to think you're getting better.
And I don't have anything like as much time to write as I wish I did, and I haven't been very prolific since I've been fouled up with being chairman.
And hopefully all that's going to end soon and I can get back to it.
But I think I've learned a few things.
I hope I have.
I know Dick Matheson always used to be terrible, you know.

The first story he ever wrote was Born a Man and Woman, and apparently it's the only one anybody ever remembered, because whenever anybody would meet Dick, you know, they would say, oh, how I enjoyed Born a Man and Woman, and he's gotten to the point he just hates to hear about it, because, you know, the implication is that you haven't written a damn thing since that anybody wants to read.
Yeah, that's true.
I hate that.
but I'd like to ask the same question about your noveling.
Novel or novelette?
Novel.
Noveling really is... You're going to say artifying boarded right into the novelette category.
It does shade into it.
Well, it wouldn't be my favorite novelette.
I was counting it as a short story.
I don't know what my favorite novel is.
I've written, I guess, more novelettes than short stories.
Favorite novel...
There's not a whole lot of room for choice here.
Like liquid bibliography?
Well, I suppose you can kind of tackle it in reverse.
I like Unearthly Neighbors least of my own novels.
That's not my title, by the way.
I hate the title.
Maybe that is one thing that puts me off.
I called that Shoulder of the Sky.
It's from Hausman.
And it got changed because some guy had written a book about the Air Force that came out right about the same time called Shoulder of the Sky.
So Valentine just stuck Unearthly Neighbors on it, which I think is just a ghastly title.
If you'll notice, if my memory's not playing tricks on me, Unearthly Neighbors is the only one of my novels, science fiction novels,
that's not very solidly rooted in the present.
I'm not sure how much I've done this as a conscious policy, or whether it's just worked out that way.
But all others have been.
They're either set in the present, or they begin in the present, or they touch the present pretty closely one way or another.
And this is not true of unearthly neighbors.
And I suspect that's one reason I'm less fond of it.
It's harder for me to get a degree of reality into a story.

If I don't have a touchstone, I don't know quite how, I don't even know what I'm trying to say exactly, except that I like science fiction that's not too far out and that has something that's recognizable, not just to other people, but to me.
So the thing is meaning, but anyway, I like that one the least.
I think that you can eliminate Miss Sedan simply because it's a juvenile.
I had some fun with that, by the way.
They had a directive when I wrote that.
Forgive me, am I going on too long about something you don't give a damn about?
I remember there was kind of a formula you were supposed to write that book to for that whole series.
Every chapter was supposed to end on a shattering climax, you know, that would make Joe Blow
age 14, rip on through the know, and I compromised.
And if you'll notice in Miss Adonna, not consistent, but frequently, I alternate chapters in which there's one chapter that's all plot and cliffhangers, and then there's one for me.
And so more or less...
Every other chapter in there is one that I wrote because I wanted to write it, and the next one is there for the story.
But we could eliminate that one.
You know, pretty soon we'll be down where there aren't any.
I think The Winds of Time is a mixed bag in that there's some things I like very much in The Winds of Time, and there are other things that I don't care for too much.
So we can eliminate that one.
And that leaves us with, what, three?
I don't know.
I guess I like Shadows in the Sun, but saying that, what it really means is that it's somewhat closer to me than the others.
I have not gone back and re-read it.
I'm sure that if I went back and re-read it, there are lots of things I wouldn't care for about it.
But I like the wolf as my brother, and I like the shores of another city.
So I don't know.
If I were forced to pick, I guess it would be between shadows in the sun and the wolf as my brother.
But I don't know.
One was your first venture in the general market, and the other one the prize market.
That's right.
Not that winning prizes says anything.
Worked a long time on that book.
I know which of the two is Dr. McAllister's favorite.
I started writing Wolf is My Brother before I left for Africa.
And I wrote a fair amount of it in Africa in the evenings, and sometimes when it was raining so hard I couldn't get out.
You may remember it from the shores of another ship.
I sometimes think my Comanches sound more like convo than anything else.
I did, I spent a good five years on it.
And I spent a good three years on Shores of Another Sea.
I don't mean constantly, but I mean that's what I was working on and what you're, what finally came out is radically different from what I started with.
Started out as a straight and all.
Dr. McAllister told me the story that
His copy of The Wolf is My Brother just suddenly appeared on his doorstep, so to speak.
He was unaware that it was in progress.
He'd been chastising you for years to get away from that silly science fiction and write something serious.
Well, I don't recall that specifically.
I remember talking about the science fiction.
Everybody does.
What do you waste your time writing that stuff?
I get that all the time.
It doesn't deter me in the least.
But I never talk about things when I write them.
I realize this sounds terribly superior and smug and all that.
Forgive me, I don't mean to sound that way.
In my experience, there are two kinds of writers, maybe three kinds.
But broadly speaking, you've got the talking writers and the writing writers.
And in my experience, the guys that spend all their time talking about
what they're going to do and what they're doing, very seldom write anything.
And I find it very hard.
It goes dead on me if I talk about it when I'm doing it.
Because whatever it is that you're trying to get down on a piece of paper and it makes you want to write the thing in the first place, it can get dissipated in telling somebody about it.
I mean, after all, that's what you're doing when you're writing the story.
But I never talk about it.
And I very seldom talk about anything I've written either, unless somebody comes in and asks me point-blank.
It's not that I'm secretive.
On the other hand, I have known writers.
Chuck Beaumont was one, who was always full of what he was writing right then.
And I had to talk about it, and couldn't wait to rip a page out of the typewriter and read it to you, you know, whether the thing was finished or not.
I've just never been...
Yes.
The collaborations with him carry this tone with them, I think.
We had more fun doing those stories than anything I've ever written.
I've never been able to collaborate really with anybody else.
There was a story that came out with my byline and Garvin Berry's on it.
You may have noticed a very early story in Super Science called The Blood Star, not my title either, and not Garvin's.
But he didn't write it.
What had happened there was we'd kicked it around together for a long time, and part of the plot was his.
And I thought it was only fair to stick his name on it, but actually Chuck's the only one I've collaborated with.
And just on that one kind of story, and we just had a ball.
Everything he wrote just knocked me out.
And we did it in sections, you know.
He would sit down and write
thousand words, you know, and give it to me, and then I'd read that and I'd type the next thousand.
And he really broke me up.
I can remember both of them.
We just, it was one of those happy things where we each amused the other.
And I remember taking his section of manuscript and reading it and actually falling out of the chair laughing, you know, and then going down and trying to do likewise.
It was great fun.
There's one other of those stories that we wrote that was never published, and I don't know what happened to it.
I don't know.
It got lost somewhere when Chuck died.
It was called The Rest of Science Fiction.
And we took all the plots that we hadn't been able to dispose of in the last word and I clubbed and took care of the rest of them.
I remember nothing about it except a lot of it was horror fiction.
And I remember the protagonist was the, let's see, how did that go?
It was the beautiful scientist and his mad daughter, which we thought was a fairly good switch.
But that's all I remember.
It was great fun.
I miss Chuck terribly.
He was a wonderful guy.
Met a terrible death.
I thought, one of these awful things where you talk about a man getting trapped in his own plot,
rather like a Lovecraftian sort of notion.
I can never remember the name of the disease, but Chuck was the same age I am.
It's this premature aging and senility syndrome, whatever it is.
I forget the last time I saw Chuck before he died.
His hair had turned snow white.
His face was all lime.
His hands were palsied.
He could feel it coming on.
Toward the end, he was just a vegetable.
He couldn't even say yes or no.
Perfectly harmless and kind of being a wonderful talented guy.
I could tell you lots of stories about Beaumont, but I guess that's not what you want.
Wasn't his real name anyway.
Seems to be fairly common.
But Chad Oliver's mother.
Yeah.
His real name was Nutt, Charles Nutt, N-U-T-T.
It's very indicative of the kind of guy he was that he would pick a name like Beaumont.
He was, even when he was desperately poor, he was very flamboyant, you know, only had one decent suit of clothes to his name, but it had a flashy red vest.
And when he really got hungry, he used to go down, you know, not to some hamburger joint or anything, he'd pick out the finest restaurant in Los Angeles.
demand to see the manager and say, sir, I am Charles Beaumont, struggling young writer.
If you stake me to a meal one day, you will be famous.
And he was never turned down.
I wonder if he could get away with it now.
I don't want to be curious.
But he sure got away with it.
It was a long time ago.
Give me another question.
I'm running now.
Were there any other writers, I assume that Beaumont and Nolan both you met, first met while you were out on the coast?
That's right.
Are there any other writers or science fiction personalities with whom you got acquainted out there?
Yeah, I knew Richard Matheson quite well.
Dick and I had never met and we were
both writing for fantasy and science fiction, carrying him side by side.
And at that time, as I said, I didn't know Dick, and had no idea that he never read science fiction, didn't care anything about it.
So I read a story of his that really impressed me, and I thought, well, gosh, here's this guy right here in Los Angeles.
I'll just call him up.
And I did.
Got him on the phone, and I said, hi, Dick, this is Chad Oliver.
It was this long silence, and then the single word
He had never heard of me.
He had no idea who I was.
So I went over and explained who I was and we got to be very close friends.
Apart from those, from Dick and Chuck and Bill, the only other ones were Bradbury, whom I knew fairly well.
We certainly were never as close as Chuck and I and Bill, who were all more or less struggling M-Riders at a time that Bradbury had already arrived.
tended to be rather paternal in his attitude toward young upstarts, which is not a fair statement.
He's a very generous kind of a guy.
And I knew Van Boot and some of the old timers out there like Ross Rocklin, Stu Byrne.
They were all over the place, but I didn't know them well.
And aside from those, actually the only writers that I know at all well are Walt Miller and
and Randall Garrett, who spent a year here.
There are others that I know casually, but not that I've ever spent a lot of time with.
You're still a member of SFWA.
Whether or not you're very active, I don't know.
But I see you mentioned in connection with any membership work that they're doing.
We can't keep people like Chad Oliver out.
That's right.
Where did you see that, or did you?
I picked this up, I can't cite the source right off the top of my head, perhaps the last bulletin.
Gosh, I must have missed that one.
This is just a guess, but they were talking about someone had to publish within the last, in X number of years, which you're going to qualify now.
Yeah, I'm qualified.
Thank you.
I hadn't published anything in several years.
Yeah, I've been a member, and
have not at all been active.
It really boils down to paying my dues.
They asked me to run for president several years ago when I declined.
There's just no way in the world that I could be president.
I mean, not that I'd get elected, but even if I did, at the same time that I'm chairman, it's just been awesome.
I can understand that.
But, yeah, I'm a member.
Seems like a good organization.
Yeah, if it doesn't...
come apart at the seams with factionalism and a lot of quarreling about things that aren't really important.
There is a danger in that.
There isn't any organization of that type, but on balance, yeah, I think it's good.
There's a new one which you may not have come across yet.
The Science Fiction Research Association has been formed.
Yes, I have.
heard something about it, and somebody sent me some material on it.
Because I recall that's the one that cost some astronomical sum to join here.
Three bucks?
Twenty bucks.
Twenty bucks.
Which, the last information I had, at least, indicates an interest in science fiction on what you might term the scholarly level, which again seems to be a...
I'm also a member of a...
Western Writers of America for what that's worth.
Rather more of an organization I fear.
I'm not an organization man.
I don't join things.
I don't like meetings and I hate conventions.
I'm one of these odd people where if I ever do get some spare time I'm down on the stream trout fishing.
These organizations
indicate an academic interest in science fiction.
Do you think this is good for the field?
I'd be real curious.
I'm not sure what you mean by good for the field.
What I really think is that it's inevitable in lots of ways.
If only on one elementary level.
I've always felt in my prejudiced manner that
for a fairly specialized, even coterie type of writing, a lot better writing in science fiction than in almost any other comparable field that I know anything about.
And that's been true for many, many years.
And the utter contempt with which it was received by outside critics, I don't know how much effect it had on the field, but it certainly hurts if you're a writer.
to always have what you write simply ignored or, well, usually ignored.
It wasn't that it was condemned, really, or torn apart by some savage critic.
It's just as though it didn't exist.
And there was a lot of writing in that period when we were being consistently ignored by everybody.
It was a damn sight better than the kind of thing that everybody was flipping over.
And I think it's still true.
There's a definite tendency in this culture
Films, books, everything.
There's a sort of masterpiece of the week club in which I've gotten to the point I never go see a film anymore where somebody has found some review that says, this will revolutionize motion pictures.
It's the greatest film in the last five years.
It's always crap.
And the same way with the novels and the novelists who are the darlings of the critics for six months or something and you never hear of them again.
There were lots of things that were being done that should have received more attention than they did.
But how much effect it actually has on the writing of science fiction is something else.
I think you could even argue it the other way.
That maybe there was an advantage in writers writing science fiction because they loved it and simply tried to do the best job they could without worrying about what some critic was going to say.
There's always a danger in writing for the critic, any critic.
It's the worst mistake you can make.
You've no doubt read the SFWA round-robin criticism.
Who needs it?
I've thumbed through it.
I think this was the genesis of the question.
People don't understand science fiction.
They still don't understand science fiction.
Most criticism of science fiction, I think, has the wrong target anyhow.
So much of it, you know, come back to what you're talking about in the article you're writing.
The idea is that the one form of science fiction that's respectable is some variant of the utopian novel, the social satire, or something of that kind.
And in large part, this is purely a personal crotchet of mine, but it's the aspect of science fiction that interests me the least.

other types of science fiction that are aimed at a different target don't get the same reception, whether you're talking about Childhood's End or More Than Human or Mechanical for Leibowitz or whoever.
Science fiction, you know, it's essentially a literary technique.
What it is, it's a way of telling a story.
And you can write any kind of story as science fiction, I think.
Joanna Russ, I believe, I hate to cite her specifically, but I've seen a lot of big-name science fiction people mention about the academic interest in science fiction.
By and large, what it is, do those academics keep their hands the hell out of our literature?
This is the genesis of the question and what was behind it.
Well, I wouldn't agree with that.
As I say, I think it's inevitable.
I mean, here it is.
If it exists, it ought to be studied, and what harm can it do?
As long as we don't take it too seriously.
That's the danger.
I believe you have written an article on the nature of science fiction that appeared in one of the fanzines.
Inside an SF advertiser sometime in 1955.
Oh gosh, I'd forgotten about that.
What is science fiction?
Yeah, I did.
It was a long time.
I'm sorry I don't remember a thing about it.
I'll try to get my hands on it.
I dimly recall writing it, and I hadn't thought about it in years.
Yeah, I did.
You're right.
What about, did you write much for the fanzines?
No.
On that nature?
No.
There were a few things, and that was some I've forgotten.
I wrote a thing, I remember, on Ray Bradbury for that book.
What was it called?
It was a one-shot, finely done thing called the Ray Bradbury Review or something that Bill Mullen put out years ago and asked me to write an article for, which I did.
And then I did that thing that you mentioned, and there are probably a few others, but I don't remember what they were.
I've never been much involved with the fan magazines, really.
except for publishing my own one time.
A one-shot.
Garvin Berry and I put out one called The Moon Puddle.
One issue.
The Moon Puddle.
Variant of The Moon Puddle by A. Murray.
We had a lot of fun with it, but we never really intended it to be a series or anything.
We just ran all 50 copies, which are priceless collector's items.
Dr. Manick has got.
I don't know where my copy is.
We wrote the whole thing.
Well, I take it back.
We wrote all of it except one article that David H. Keller submitted at that period where he was submitting everything to all of them.
I had an article in there about Edgar Rice Burroughs and Garvin had a perfectly marvelous thing on Henry Kuttner in which he set out to try to track down every pen name that
Henry Kuttner ever used, which was an Olympian undertaking.
I knew Kuttner also, I forgot.
Fascinating kid.
You never did write any pseudonym, did you?
Did you always use your own name?
Does that tell me the question?
No, I was just trying to remember if I ever had.
I don't think so.
If I did, I don't recall.
never had any reason.
I mean, after all, I'm not that prolific.
That's primary reason for the pseudonyms at that point.
It was in the old days, where it just looked awkward to have a contents page that had been entirely written by one individual, although sometimes they did that, you know, more or less as a gimmick.
I remember, I think Don Wilcox wrote a whole issue of Amazing Stories one time, but it was done actually for two reasons.
One,
to avoid the argument, well he can't be any good if he writes that.
And the other people who had radically different styles, and they wanted to keep them separate, and that definitely was a factor with Kuttner.
He wrote totally differently as Henry Kuttner and as Lewis Padgett, for example.
And for a long time, nobody knew who Lewis Padgett wrote.
And then he and his wife, C.L.
Moore, collaborated on a number of things and used some other name.
What was that?
Lawrence O'Donnell.
I don't know what the name was.
Whatever it was.
But he had a whole raft of them.
Keith Hammond was another one.
A number of these people have unbelievable variety of suitors.
The guy that amazes me is Paul Anderson.
He is so prolific.
And the quality is so high.
And he's been doing it for so long.
That is amazing.
Yeah.
There are lots of writers that have creative spurts and turn out a number of really fine things within a fairly short period of time and then more or less tail off and just dribble out a story.
Ted Sturgeon, to a degree, is like that.
He's written very little really lately, at least that I'm aware of.
And these fantastic creative explosions like Heinlein had at one time, again under a variety of different managers.
But somebody that can sustain it over the years, like Pohl does, is really amazing.
I knew him, too.
I forgot.
Not well.
Pohl lived in Berkeley.
And several times when I went up to talk to Boucher, I'd get together with Pohl or Meyer very much, which is probably obvious.
I enjoy reading much of his material.
I've got a new to me paperback that he's written.
Yeah, it's the kind of thing where there are not too many Paul Anderson stories that you can look back on and say, boy, that's the greatest thing I ever read.
But on the other hand, there are very few you'll ever read that you put down and say, boy, that's a total waste of time, a real stinker.
He's a real pro, is what they've done.
That's true, too.
I have a curiosity.
Have you read Heinlein's new contribution?
No.
I saw it.
in the serial version in what, Galaxy?
I read something about it somewhere, just one comment that I have not read.
In fact, I haven't read a fair amount of it over the later Heinlein.
I'm ashamed to say I've read Stranger in a Strange Land and I've read The Moon is a Harsh Mistress.
And I think that's about all fairly recent.
I guess it's not really recent to you, Heinlein.
So isn't this the one about the sex switch?
It's a brain transplant, basically what it is.
Coupled with a sex switch, I guess you could say.
Getting good.
I wouldn't read it again if I had my choice.
It has received uniformly poor reviews.
Well, maybe there's something to it.
It's an interesting thing.
I think he was going around experimenting a bit himself.
Well, there's a guy who I think contributed a tremendous amount to science fiction, particularly in terms of technique.
During that one period where Heinlein was really turning them out, both as Heinlein and as Anson MacDonald, I think it would be very hard to point to any comparable
what was it, three-year period by any one writer in which so many knew.
